The Convention.that the restrictions on the employment of children shall be prescribed and enforced by national laws and regulations. This system differs from that in operation in the United Kingdom under which general regulations laid down by statute allowed Local Education Authorities to supplement these regulations by bye-laws laying down more detailed restrictions subject to the approval of the Central Department.3. So far as the existing practice in England and Wales is concerned, the two main obstacles to ratification are to be found in the provisions of the Convention which (l) prohibit all employment, even of a light character, before 8 a.m. and (2) limit employment during school holidays to two hours a day. The employment of children under 14 in Great Britain has been strictly regulated for many years by statute and by local bye-laws. Employment on school days is limited in England to two hours a day, and Local Authorities are authorised by bye-laws to allow employment before school for one hour. Many Local Authorities have made such bye-laws so as to permit children to be employed before school in light work such as delivering milk and newspapers, which are the principal occupations in which school children are engaged. Local bye-laws generally restrict employment during school holidays to four or five hours a day. If employers could only obtain the services of children after 8 a.m. and then for two hours a day, whether during school holidays or otherwise, it would not be worth while in most cases employing them at all. The effect, therefore, of this draft Convention so far as England is concerned, would go far to prohibit altogether the employment of school children.1.We have to decide on the action to be taken regarding the Draft2.The Convention, the text of which is printed in Cmd.4115 attached, requires 1794. As regards Scotland, there has boon no limitation of work on school days to two hours a day until the Children and Young Persons (Scotland) Act, 1932, came into operation last autumn. The Act represents a considerable change of practice and also for the first time fixed 12 years as the minimum statutory age for employment in Scotland (though this age had been generally adopted in bye-laws) and has placed a statutory limit of two hours on employment on Sundays or school days.5. In 1931, when enquiries were made, the Local Education Authorities, both inEngland and Wales and in Scotland, were with few exceptions, satisfied with the operation of the existing restrictions and did not wish to prevent the comparatively small amount of employment which takes place either before school or otherwise.6. Furthermore, the law on the subject was considered by Parliament in 1932and re-enacted in the Children and Young Persons Act, 1932. The Children and Young Persons Act, 1933 (which consolidated the Act of 1932 with other enactments) only came into force on 1st November, 1953, and it is too early to form an opinion whether Local Authorities are likely in making new bye-laws to propose restrictions going far beyond those which are found in their existing bye-laws. 7. Our delegates made it quite clear at the International Labour Conferenceof 1932 that the proposals contained in the draft Convention were inconsistent with the system in force here and unacceptable in some of the main principles. The majority of the Conference, however, declined to meet these representations,and in accordance with the instructions given to them our delegates abstained from voting when the Convention came up for final adoption. No charge of bad faith can fairly be brought if this country does not adopt the Convention. 8. In the circumstances described above, we do not think that H.M. Governmentwould be justified at the present time in.proposing legislation to place such further restrictions on the employment of school children as would be necessary to enable the Convention to be ratified.9. On the other hand, we do not think that it is necessary to close the doorfinally as circumstances may change within a period of years. There are some educationalists who are in favour of preventing all employment of children under the age of 14, and this is also the view generally of the Labour Party. 10. During the passage of the Children and Young Persons Act in 1932, it was stated that, when the industrial position improved, legislation might be introduced dealing with this matter and an announcement now that it was proposed to leave the law unaltered would not pass without comment. That this is the case is indicated by the interest taken in the subject at the Trades Union Congress last September and by a Recommendation in the Fifth Report of the Scottish National Advisory Council for Juvenile Employment in May, 1932, to the effect that the abolition of part-time employment before and after school hours would probably result in an increase in the demand for juveniles who have left school, and that Juvenile Advisory Committees deprecate the part-time emplojoiient of children who have not left school.11. The number of unemployed young persons over 14 it likely to rise in the next few years owing to the increase in the birth rate immediately after the end of the War, and this may be expected to harden public opinion in favour of reducing further the employment of children of school age so as to extend the opportunities of those who have left school. Furthermore, a time when severe unemployment continues to prevail seems to be an unsuitable one for a final decision ago.inst ratification of a Convention of this kind.12.. v?e are under the obligation of the Treaty of Versailles to bring the Convention before the "competent authority" and this obligation is normally met by a White Paper containing the proposals of the Government. In the circumstances we suggest that the best course to pursue would be to lay a paper stating that the proposals in the Convention in certain material points go beyond the law relating to the employment of school children in this country, which was reviewed by Parliament as recently as 1932. The new law only came into operation on 1st November, 1933, and it is too soon to form any opinion as to how it willwork in practice. The Government does not propose to take a final decision on the question of the ratification of the Convention and of the enabling legislation which would be required but intends to keep the matter under consideration for the time being. Re commendation.13. The Recommendation which was adopted at the same time as the Convention was intended to secure uniform application of the Convention. Although the suggestior contained in it are in general acceptable, no useful purpose would be served by formally accepting it without prior ratification of the Convention on which it is dependent. We suggest, therefore, that the same action should be followed in regard to it as in the case of the Convention.(INTLD.) J.G.19th September, 1934. G.C.* ' O.S.
